title: When Sport and Type Collide
content:
Hey there,

Welcome to my first post. Been lurking for a long while now but am now taking the plunge.

It's rare that sport and typography come together but these new Australian soccer jerseys have been a talking point amongst even typographic novices. What is the face used in the names and numbers? Weirdly, there are many dying to know.

Thanks in advance.

[http://www.ccmariners.com.au/\_content/image/00003902-image.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20121109100445/http:/www.ccmariners.com.au/_content/image/00003902-image.jpg "http://www.ccmariners.com.au/\_content/image/00003902-image.jpg")

[http://www.geocities.com/sydneyfc06/brosque2b.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20121109100445/http:/www.geocities.com/sydneyfc06/brosque2b.jpg "http://www.geocities.com/sydneyfc06/brosque2b.jpg")
author: Phormic

comments.content:
Hi Phormic,  
it is more like: when sports and money collide. Almost all big sportsbrands now have their custom designed typefaces to keep the merchandising money in the pocket.

So, as a start, have a look at [this website](http://web.archive.org/web/20121109100445/http:/www.metro-sport.com/) for example, to see how many leagues are playing with licenced typefaces.
